metadata.title: Improved performance of AlGaN-based deep ultraviolet light-emitting diodes with nano-patterned AlN/sapphire substrates

sections.text:
Improved performance of AlGaN-based deep ultraviolet light-emitting diodes with nano-patterned AlN/sapphire substrates Donghyun Lee, Jong Won Lee, Jeonghwan Jang, In-Su Shin, Lu Jin, Jun Hyuk Park, Jungsub Kim, Jinsub Lee, Hye-Seok Noh, Yong-Il Kim, Youngsoo Park, Gun-Do Lee, Yongjo Park, Jong Kyu Kim, and Euijoon Yoon
Citation: Appl. Phys. Lett. 110, 191103 (2017); doi: 10.1063/1.4983283 View online: http://dx.doi.org/10.1063/1.4983283 View Table of Contents: http://aip.scitation.org/toc/apl/110/19 Published by the American Institute of Physics

High temperature operation of n-AlGaN channel metal semiconductor field effect transistors on low-defect AlN templates Appl. Phys. Lett. 110, 193501193501 (2017); 10.1063/1.4982656
Improved performance of AlGaN-based deep ultraviolet light-emitting diodes with nano-patterned AlN/sapphire substrates
Donghyun Lee,1,a) Jong Won Lee,2,a) Jeonghwan Jang,1 In-Su Shin,1 Lu Jin,1 Jun Hyuk Park,2 Jungsub Kim,3 Jinsub Lee,3 Hye-Seok Noh,3 Yong-Il Kim,3 Youngsoo Park,3 Gun-Do Lee,1 Yongjo Park,4 Jong Kyu Kim,2,b) and Euijoon Yoon1,4,5,b) 1Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Seoul National University, Seoul 08826, South Korea 2Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Pohang University of Science and Technology, Pohang 37673, South Korea 3Advanced Development Team, LED Business, Samsung Electronics, Yongin 17113, South Korea 4Energy Semiconductor Research Center, Advanced Institutes of Convergence Technology, Seoul National University, Suwon 16229, South Korea 5Research Institute of Advanced Materials and Inter-university Semiconductor Research Center, Seoul National University, Seoul 08826, South Korea
(Received 15 January 2017; accepted 28 April 2017; published online 11 May 2017)
We demonstrated AlGaN-based deep ultraviolet light-emitting diodes (DUV LEDs) with periodic air-voids-incorporated nanoscale patterns enabled by nanosphere lithography and epitaxial lateral overgrowth (ELO) on a 4-in. sapphire substrate. The nanoscale ELO improved the crystal quality of overgrown epitaxial layers at a relatively low growth temperature of 1050 C and at small coalescence thickness less than 2 lm. The light output power of the DUV LED was enhanced significantly by 67% at an injection current of 20 mA. We attribute such a remarkable enhancement to the formation of embedded periodic air voids which cause simultaneous improvements in the crystal quality of epitaxial layers by ELO and light extraction efficiency enabled by breaking the predominant in-plane guided propagation of DUV photons. Published by AIP Publishing. [http://dx.doi.org/10.1063/1.4983283]
AlGaN-based deep ultraviolet (DUV) light-emitting diodes (LEDs) have attracted much attention due to their various applications such as water purification, sterilization, curing, and bio-agent detection.1 However, the external quantum efficiency (EQE) of AlGaN-based DUV LEDs (typically less than 10% for 280 nm LEDs) is much lower than that of InGaN-based visible LEDs (60% for 450 nm blue LEDs) due to intrinsic material properties of AlGaN which lead to poor internal quantum efficiency (IQE) and light extraction efficiency (LEE).2 Increasing the Al composition x in AlxGa1–xN for the emission of deeper UV photons generally leads to a high density of extended defects such as threading dislocations and cracks due to the large lattice mismatch and thermal mismatch between the AlGaN epitaxial layer and foreign substrates as well as the low surface mobility of Al-containing alloys. These extended defects are known to act as non-radiative recombination centers and thus cause low IQE.3–5 In addition, the LEE of AlGaN-based DUV LEDs is severely limited due to strong absorption of DUV photons by the top p-type GaN contact layer and light trapping by total internal reflection particularly for the strong anisotropic transverse-magnetic polarized emission from the AlGaN active region.6,7 Since the EQE is determined by both IQE and LEE, in order to overcome such significant limitations in EQE, thus, to realize highly efficient DUV LEDs, it is essential to enhance the IQE by realization of high quality AlGaN epitaxial layers and the LEE simultaneously.
Several growth techniques such as migration-enhanced epitaxy8 and multilayer-AlN buffer growth by the ammonia (NH3) pulse-flow method 9 have been reported to reduce the threading dislocation density (TDD) in AlN on sapphire by enhancing the surface migration of Al-species.8,9 Epitaxial lateral overgrowth (ELO) on microscale patterned sapphire substrates and AlN/sapphire substrates has been investigated, demonstrating the reduction of TDD and the enhancement of the light output power (LOP) of UV LEDs.10–14 However, ELO on microscale patterned substrates requires high growth temperature above 1300 C for enough surface migration of Al adatoms and a long growth time for the coalescence of AlN over the wing region, thus high cost. Recently, Dong et al. suggested nanoscale ELO of AlN on nano-patterned sapphire substrates at the growth temperature of 1200 C to reduce the coalescence gap as well as to increase the light scattering and have achieved an enhanced EQE.15 Conroy et al. also have reported nanoscale ELO of AlN on a uniform array of 1 lm-thick AlN nanorods on the sapphire substrate at the growth temperature of 1100 C, showing an improved crystal quality of the overgrown AlN films.16 Although thinner coalescence thicknesses and high quality AlN layers were accomplished by the nanoscale ELO, careful consideration should be given to the effect of nanoscale patterns and resultant formation of a periodic refractive-index contrast between the AlN layer and air on the extraction of DUV photons and thus on the EQE in order to further improve the efficiency of DUV LEDs.
In this work, we report a remarkable enhancement in LOP of AlGaN-based DUV LEDs enabled by a nanoscale ELO of AlN on nano-patterned substrates (NPS) resulting in a)D. Lee and J. W. Lee contributed equally to this work. b)Authors to whom correspondence should be addressed: kimjk@postech.ac. kr and eyoon@snu.ac.kr
0003-6951/2017/110(19)/191103/5/$30.00 Published by AIP Publishing.110, 191103-1
an embedded air-void nanostructure. The nanoscale ELO on the NPS improved the crystal quality of overgrown AlN layers, reducing the growth temperature and the coalescence thickness. In addition, the periodically embedded air-void nanostructure formed in the AlN layer enhanced the LEE by breaking the total internal reflection that is particularly severe for the predominant anisotropic emission in AlGaN-based DUV LEDs. The LOP of the DUV LEDs was enhanced significantly by 67% at an injection current of 20 mA due to simultaneous improvements in the crystal quality of epitaxial layers, i.e., IQE and LEE.
Figure 1(a) is a schematic fabrication process of AlN/sapphire NPS. A 1.3 lm-thick AlN layer was grown on a 4-in. c-plane sapphire substrate (0.35 miscut toward the m-plane) by an Aixtron G3 metal-organic chemical vapor deposition (MOCVD) system. Trimethylaluminum (TMAl), trimethylgallium (TMGa), and NH3 were used as the sources of Al, Ga, and N, respectively. In order to obtain a flat surface of AlN and suppress parasitic reactions between TMAl and NH3, the V/III ratio was lowered to 160 for AlN growth. Then, the silica nanosphere lithography technique was employed to fabricate the NPS. The silica nanospheres with average diameter of 700 nm were synthesized by the St€ober method.17 Selfassembled silica nanospheres as etch masks were coated on the AlN layer uniformly over the 4-in. wafer by spin coating. Then, Cl2-based reactive ion etching was carried out to transfer the nanosphere pattern to the underlying AlN layer. The residual silica nanospheres after the etching were cleaned by dipping the substrate in hydrofluoric acid. Figures 1(b) and 1(c) are plan-view and bird’s-eye-view scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of the fabricated NPS. A welldefined hexagonal array of AlN nanorods with c-plane flat top surfaces on the sapphire substrate was obtained after the nanosphere lithography. The resultant diameter and height of nanorods were measured to be 630 nm and 1.3 lm, respectively. The air spacing between the nanorods along the center-to-center direction was about 130 nm, which was small enough to enable the coalescence of overgrown AlN layers on the nanorods overcoming the limited surface migration of Al adatoms.
The NPS was loaded again into the MOCVD reactor to grow the AlN layer on it. ELO of AlN on NPS was performed at a growth temperature of 1050 C, which is much lower than that for microscale ELO (1300–1400 C)10–14 and even lower than that for former nanoscale ELO (1100–1200 C).15,16 The
surface temperature of the MOCVD susceptor, defined as the growth temperature in this study, was measured using a pyrometer. Growth conditions for ELO of AlN were the same as those used for the growth of the AlN layer on the planar sapphire substrate. No pulsed growth mode was used for AlN on NPS. For a comparative study, reference AlN was grown on the planar AlN layer at the same time. Figure 2 shows the structure of the AlN layer grown on the NPS characterized by SEM and atomic force microscopy (AFM). Figures 2(a) and 2(b) are cross-section and plan-view SEM images of the 5.2 lm-thick AlN layer overgrown on the NPS. Note that, despite the much lower growth temperature, the AlN completely coalesced within 2 lm overgrowth, indicating much faster coalescence compared to the previous microscale ELO results,10–14 thanks to the ELO of AlN on nanoscale patterns as reported in the previous results.15,16 The reduction of both growth temperature and growth thickness for ELO of AlN by introducing the NPS can directly lead to much reduced manufacturing cost. In addition, air voids surrounding the AlN nanorods were formed periodically between the overgrown AlN layer and the sapphire substrate as a result of the ELO of AlN on top of the nanorods. It is expected that the embedded air voids can (i) relieve the stress of the AlN film by reducing the contact area between the epitaxial layer and the underlying substrate and (ii) make a periodic refractiveindex contrast between air and AlN. Figure 2(b) shows a fully coalesced top surface of the AlN layer. Zigzag macro-steps along [1100]AlN observed on the SEM image and also identified by the AFM image shown in Figure 2(c) originate from the miscut of the sapphire substrate, as reported previously.18 While there were cracks on the surface of reference AlN, crack-free AlN layers were obtained on NPS over the whole 4-in. wafer. The tensile stress is built up with increasing the thickness of AlN layers during the growth and the
accumulated stress leads to the crack formation. As investigated by Conroy et al.,16 the embedded air voids formed in the AlN epitaxial layer effectively released the tensile stress induced in the AlN layer during the growth, so that the thick and crack-free AlN layer was grown on the NPS.
To evaluate the crystal qualities of the AlN layers, X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurement was carried out. Figures 3(a) and 3(b) are X-ray rocking curves of symmetric (002) and asymmetric (102) reflections of AlN layers with normalized peak intensities. The full width at half maximum (FWHM) values of (002) planes were 186 and 235 arc sec for the AlN on NPS and the reference AlN, respectively, and those of (102) planes were measured to be 432 and 457 arc sec for the AlN on NPS and the reference AlN, respectively. The reduction of FWHM values of both (002) and (102) reflections indicates that the crystal quality of AlN layers grown on NPS was improved by nanoscale ELO.
An Al0.43Ga0.57 N/Al0.58Ga0.42 N multiple-quantum well (MQW) DUV LED was grown on the NPS with a 3 lm-thick AlN buffer layer. The DUV LED consists of AlN/AlGaN superlattice buffer layers, a 2.4 lm-thick Si-doped n-type Al0.58Ga0.42N layer, five periods of MQWs composed of 2 nm-thick Al0.43Ga0.57N quantum wells and 10 nm-thick Al0.58Ga0.42N quantum barriers, a 15 nm-thick Mg-doped Al0.8Ga0.2N electron blocking layer, a Mg-doped p-type AlGaN cladding layer with a graded Al composition from 58% to 0%, and a 200 nm-thick Mg-doped p-type GaN contact layer. For a reference, the AlN layer and DUV LED
were also grown on a planar AlN template without the patterning in the MOCVD reactor. TDDs in n-AlGaN layers measured by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) were 4.4 109 cm 2 and 6.0 109 cm 2 for the DUV LED on NPS and the reference DUV LED, respectively. The reduced TDD indicates the improved crystal quality of AlN and overgrown AlGaN thereon by ELO (see supplementary material). The DUV LEDs on NPS and the reference DUV LEDs were fabricated with a chip size of 300 300 lm2 by using conventional GaN-based LED fabrication processes (see supplementary material). To avoid the possible performance variation over the 4-in. wafers, the center parts of both wafers were used.
Figure 4(a) shows the representative current-voltage (I-V) characteristics for both reference DUV LED and DUV LED on NPS. The inset shows electroluminescence (EL) intensity as a function of wavelength, showing the emission with a peak wavelength of 280 nm without parasitic emission. The reference DUV LED has much higher forward leakage current than that of the DUV LED on NPS. Reducing forward leakage is very important for improving overall performance of LEDs because it is correlated with device reliability and power consumption. The high forward leakage is commonly believed to be defect-assisted tunneling
current resulting from high-density defects in III-nitride films heteroeptaxially grown on foreign substrates.19,20 The forward leakage of the DUV LED on NPS is significantly reduced compared to the reference DUV LED because nanoscale ELO on the NPS method can efficiently reduce the defects and improve the crystal quality of overgrown AlGaN layers. In addition, the carrier mobility is also increased in the DUV LED on NPS because of reduced grain boundaries and defects, resulting in low sheet resistance.21 As a result, at the injection current of 20 mA, the operating voltage of the DUV LED on NPS is 9.3 6 0.16 V, 1.5 V smaller than that of the reference DUV LED (10.8 6 0.66 V), which is attributed to the reduced sheet resistance in the DUV LED on NPS.
Figure 4(b) shows the average LOP with error bars as a function of the injection current measured from 50 LEDs at room-temperature. The relative EQE, estimated by dividing the photocurrent by the injection current, is also shown in the inset. The LOP of the DUV LEDs on NPS shows much higher LOP by 67% than that of the reference DUV LED at the injection current of 20 mA. Consequently, the DUV LED on NPS shows a remarkably higher relative EQE throughout the whole injection current than that of the reference DUV LED. It is worthwhile to note that efficiency peak point and efficiency droop behavior are different for both DUV LEDs. The DUV LED on NPS has a peak efficiency at 2.6 mA and an efficiency droop of 25.7% when the current is increased up to 20 mA, while the reference DUV LED shows low peak efficiency and little efficiency droop without a pronounced efficiency peak. Based on a model describing the rates of carrier recombination mechanisms, EQE can be expressed by a combination of the carrier concentration in the active region (n), defect-related non-radiative Shockley-Read-Hall (SRH) coefficient (A), and radiative coefficient (B) as follows:
EQE ¼ LEE IQE ¼ LEE Bn 2
Anþ Bn2 þ f nð Þ ;
where f(n) represents the carrier loss rate by electron leakage and Auger recombination. For the reference DUV LED with lower crystal quality, i.e., higher point defects and extended defects such as threading dislocations and grain boundaries, the SRH non-radiative lifetime is sufficiently short to suppress the radiative recombination, and thus, the radiative recombination is never dominant, resulting in a very low efficiency without a pronounced efficiency peak.22 Consequently, efficiency droop is not observed at measured currents up to 20 mA. In the case of the DUV LED on NPS with smaller A than that of the reference DUV LED, the radiative recombination process becomes dominant at a low current, followed by the pronounced efficiency droop phenomenon when other non-radiative mechanisms such as electron leakage and Auger recombination become dominant as the current increases.
The three-dimensional (3-D) finite-difference timedomain (FDTD) method (Lumerical FDTD Solutions) was used to analyze the effect of the embedded air-void nanostructure in the AlN layer on the light extraction. See supplementary material for details of the FDTD simulation models. Figure 5 shows the light propagation at 2 fs intervals in DUV LEDs without [(a)–(c)–(e)–(g)] and with the embedded air-
void nanostructure [(b)–(d)–(f)–(h)]. For the reference DUV LED, the light emitted from the MQW active region radiates in all directions. As a result, most of the light experiences the total internal reflection at the interfaces between AlN/ sapphire and sapphire/air, resulting in the huge DUV light loss due to the absorption in the strongly DUV lightabsorbing p-type GaN and MQWs. On the other hand, the light emitted from the MQWs in the DUV LEDs with the embedded air-void nanostructure propagates vertically by passing through the embedded structure. Thus, more DUV photons can be extracted via shorter photon path length before being absorbed by the p-type GaN and MQWs, avoiding the total internal reflection. The result indicates that the embedded air-void nanostructure in the DUV LEDs contributed to the enhancement of LEE remarkably.
In summary, we demonstrated AlGaN-based DUV LEDs with periodic air-voids-incorporated nanoscale patterns enabled by nanosphere lithography and ELO. The nanoscale ELO on the NPS improved the crystal quality of overgrown epitaxial layers at a relatively low growth temperature of 1050 C and at small coalescence thickness less than 2lm. The air voids formed in the AlN epitaxial layer effectively relaxed the tensile stress during growth, so that crack-free DUV LED epitaxial layers were obtained on a 4-in. sapphire substrate. In addition, the periodically embedded air-void nanostructure enhanced the LEE of DUV LEDs by breaking the total internal reflection that is particularly severe for the predominant anisotropic emission in
AlGaN-based DUV LEDs. The LOP of the DUV LEDs on NPS was enhanced by 67% at the injection current of 20 mA compared to that of the reference DUV LEDs. We believe that the significant enhancement of LOP was attributed to the simultaneous improvements in the crystal quality of AlGaN epitaxial layer, i.e., IQE and LEE.
See supplementary material for TEM analysis, LED fab-
rication processes, and FDTD simulation models.
